Award.AwardTitle: RCN-UBE Incubator: ALIVE, a platform for facilitating Authentic Learning In Virtual tropical Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical biomes play major roles in global water, carbon, and nutrient cycling and support a large proportion of the Earth's biodiversity. Despite their ecological importance, tropical ecosystems receive scant coverage in undergraduate biology textbooks and courses. Researchers in tropical ecology have developed a rich set of learning materials that could be adapted for the classroom, but a means for networking with undergraduate biology educators to disseminate these learning materials does not currently exist. The goals of this Incubator project are to 1) begin developing the Authentic Learning In Virtual tropical Environments (ALIVE) network by organizing and conducting a two-day workshop that brings together researchers in tropical ecology, educators, media specialists, and database engineers; and 2) write and submit a review/concept paper about authentic classroom-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) in tropical ecology. The long-term vision of the PIs is that the ALIVE network will develop a web-based platform to disseminate the tropical ecology learning materials it develops and that facilitates direct communication between students in the classroom and tropical field researchers.

This Incubator project aims to enhance undergraduate biology by integrating two practices, the use of CUREs and internationalization of curricula. Although CUREs can address the challenge of providing students research-based experiences, their development is often beyond the reach of many faculty, especially for CUREs based on international research. There is thus a need for a platform that integrates research in tropical biology with best practices in pedagogy. New educational materials and a community that fosters communication between students, educators, and tropical field researchers will enhance student engagement in undergraduate courses and broaden cultural, ethnic, and geographic perspectives. Although study-abroad programs can introduce students to tropical biology, only a relatively small proportion of students can participate. Students from underrepresented and/or socioeconomically disadvantaged groups may be the least able to participate, thus widening the opportunity gap for these students. Incorporating authentic research in tropical ecology into classroom-based activities will level the playing field, enabling all students to gain experience in international research in the classroom.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The over-arching goal of this project was to initiate and expand a network that brings together tropical ecology researchers, active learning pedagogy specialists, software developers, and media specialists, with the vision of creating an open-access, online resource library of learning modules in tropical ecology. The goal of these modules is to spark excitement in undergraduate biology courses by broadening cultural and geographic perspectives, enhancing principle-based reasoning in ecology, and changing the way that students learn biology.

During this successful Incubator project that started with 10 participants, the network expanded to engage a diverse, multidisciplinary community of over 60 faculty members and students. Strong foundations have been laid for continued expansion during the next 5-year-long phase of the network, and its sustainability thereafter, through various activities. Engagement with other research-coordinated networks in undergraduate biology (RCN-UBE), other NSF projects, and one non-governmental organization initiated several new collaborations, including ones dedicated to increasing participation of underrepresented groups and community colleges.

Participants created five new 'example' modules, available on an open-source, online platform, gala (www.learngala.com). One module, 'Snapshot Serengeti', has been used in multiple introductory biology courses at three institutions. A survey at the University of Minnesota found that 76% of students believed that the data analysis (R-shiny) applications that are embedded in the module made them more comfortable with analyzing and thinking about data. The new modules also ignited student interest in biology at the University of Wisconsin, where students commented that the module showed them a whole new way of collecting and analyzing data. Students loved the idea of connecting participation in online citizen science projects with the use of software programs for data analysis.

A new program, the Learning Innovation Fellows Program, was developed in conjunction with the NSF-funded Midwest Big Data Hub project. Through a series of virtual 'Networkshops', a term coined by participants for team-working via Zoom during the COVID-19 pandemic, this program connected undergraduate data science majors, graduate/professional students, faculty, and professionals to pilot a means for developing open-source software innovations that make it easier to incorporate data analysis into the online module activities. This program piloted inclusive ways of introducing prototype models into classrooms for problem-driven, data-rich material that speaks to lived infrastructural and environmental challenges from a range of communities across the globe. During the process of creating example modules, participants in our network began creating toolkits and author guidelines that will streamline processes for future module authors, including using media productions in their modules and obtaining publisher permissions and copyright assurance.

A diverse community of faculty and Ph.D. students are already becoming empowered to create online modules based on their own research, and to incorporate data-rich learning into these modules. This is evidenced by the fact that 11 faculty and graduate students launched into piloting example modules, without prior programming experience. Four of the module creators were from under-represented groups. Two module authors were from a minority-serving institution and one from an R2 university.   

Opportunities for training for undergraduate and Masters students occurred through the Learning Innovation Fellows Program, in which a diverse group of students tackled software development that enables the online modules to address ecological questions that require data analysis. The five student fellows are from under-represented groups and three are female. Opportunities for professional development for faculty and Ph.D. students occurred via participation in our virtual workshops that allowed participants to gain insights into how to create their own online modules, improve their active learning methods in their teaching, incorporate media into their modules, improve accessibility of their learning materials, and obtain publisher permission and copyright assurance. Dissemination of results occurred via five presentations at three professional meetings, and one manuscript (in review).

Faculty in fields other than ecology are already using our process for creating online modules, as evidenced by our collaboration with the NSF RCN-UBE project 'High-throughput Discovery Science & Inquiry-based Case Studies for Today's Students.' Expansion of our network has also had synergistic effects for collaborating professional societies, who are struggling during the COVID-19 pandemic to develop online modules. Our network is helping to facilitate the transition to online learning for what were traditionally field-based courses.

By fostering communication between researchers, educators, students, and software developers, this new network is beginning to facilitate educational experiences that provide a novel way for engaging students and addressing emerging instructional needs of the 21st century. The network is beginning to develop pathways for faculty to create, adopt, and share teaching innovations in a way that has not been possible previously. The example modules created thus far are already changing the way that undergraduates learn biology. Educational experiences incorporating real research, data analysis, and global perspectives in tropical ecology provide a way to develop core competencies in biology, and these abilities transcend disciplines to build foundations for excellence in diverse career paths.
